message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: 
```java
import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.StringTokenizer;

class TitleApplier {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String name;
        String[] males = {"Elroy", "Fred", "Graham"};
        String[] females = {"Amy", "Buffy", "Cathy"};
        Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);

        while (true) {
            System.out.println("Enter a name: ");
            name = scan.nextLine();
            if (name.equals("")) {
                break;
            }
            StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(name);
            String firstName = st.nextToken();

            boolean isMale = false;
            boolean isFemale = false;

            for (String male : males) {
                if (male.equals(firstName)) {
                    isMale = true;
                    break;
                }
            }

            for (String female : females) {
                if (female.equals(firstName)) {
                    isFemale = true;
                    break;
                }
            }

            if (isMale) {
                System.out.println("Mr. " + name);
            } else if (isFemale) {
                System.out.println("Ms. " + name);
            } else {
                System.out.println(name);
            }
        }
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: The StringTokenizer.nextToken API is used to break a string into tokens. In this case, it is used to get the first name from the full name entered by the user. The first name is then compared with the list of male and female names. If the first name matches any name in the male list, "Mr." is appended before the full name. If it matches any name in the female list, "Ms." is appended. If it doesn't match any name in both lists, the full name is printed as is. The program continues to ask for names until the user enters an empty string.
